awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Leveraging the computational power of a quantum annealer to optimize the methods and technologies in the logistics and supply-chain industry
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of technology to increase efficiency and reduce the costs incurred in decision-making that involves multiple variables along with several possible combinations of such variables. This technology leverages the power of a Quantum Computer (QC) for a faster and more efficient computational potential, which helps businesses in rapid decision making. This proposed technology may be applied to several industry segments such as finance, logistics and supply chain, and drug discovery. In particular, logistics and supply chain companies may benefit significantly from this technology by making faster and more efficient decisions on route to optimization, warehouse management, inventory management, and last-mile delivery.  This may allow companies to reduce fuel emissions, spend less on energy, and improve customer service. Companies also may save on resource management and reduced errors in judgment, where a small fraction of cost savings result in large savings. Commercializing this technology may have an economic benefit as well as a positive impact from an environmental perspective.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a set of algorithms to solve complex distribution problems.  Based on a COVID-19 vaccine distribution model, the solution targets advising and monitoring a safe reopening process by suggesting measures to be implemented by businesses within cities and counties.  The algorithms will also suggest effective supply distributions patterns to optimize impact on limited resource and to develop and enhance mitigation procedures and supply delivery processes for potential large-scale disasters. This proposed technology has the potential to help address critical elements relevant to emergency and disaster mitigation as well as better and more efficient distributions of goods. The goal is to develop a full-fledged software product to be used by a variety of businesses.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.inst_name: Ronin Institute for Independent Scholarship Incorporated
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: RONIN INSTITUTE FOR INDEPENDENT SCHOLARSHIP INC

por.por_cntn:
To address our main goal of developing a software product, possibly a SaaS system to be used by a variety of businesses, we have interviewed more than two hundred (200+) decision-makers at various companies about their distribution processes, logistics, and day-to-day activities and needs, various suppliers of materials about their processes; as well as attending more than ten (>10) large professional networking events to understand the specific market segments and the role of the government and policymakers about various supply chain and logistic industries.


Some of the logistics and supply chain industries and market segments explored (>10) by the team are related to the medical & health care sector, cold-chain supplies and facility builders, retail, fresh food, beverages, and seafood distributions, farming, wine-making & winery operations, as well as warehousing & fulfillment centers, and third-party logistics & enterprise resource planning.

Since the COVID-19 pandemic was a natural focal point for problem solvers and entrepreneurs, our team has  studied the medical & health care sector during our iCorps participation at the Berkeley immersive course in August 2020. By the beginning of our iCorps Teams training program in the spring of 2021, the safe reopening of cities and counties has been on its way due to the increased vaccination rate and the application of various other health measures. As a result, we have shifted our customer discovery focus to the supply chains relevant to retail and perishable products, especially the cold-chain supplies and logistics.


Cold-chain food distribution is well-developed in the USA, but this is not the case in many other countries, especially in Africa and Latin America, where there is a lack of refrigerated containers, tracks, and storage facilities.

 

The key challenges identified are most often related to vehicles and customers. On-time delivery and communication between vendors and customers is a recurring issue for a variety of businesses and across industries. The utilization of fuel is very expensive in the supply chain logistics but often the main concern of the companies was the shortage of truck drivers. The shortage problem is particularly prominent due to the pandemic considerations. Shortage of good workers and helpers is also experienced across all the industries such as retail, wine and beverages, and especially seasonal businesses.


Based on our interviews of more than 200 decision-makers and interactions with more than 10 market segments in variety of supply chain businesses, we explored about 20 different hypotheses and concluded that there are many complex distribution problems to be solved. However, we deduced that the relevant current solutions to the key supply chain challenges may be more effectively addressed by system updates and modernization of communication and management systems based on standard computational tools and technologies. In this respect, the way we anticipate quantum computing to be useful to businesses in the near future is to assess, on an annual or bi-annual scale, the efficiency of the implemented processes and measures and their level of optimality. Therefore, this is one of our explorations for the future applications of quantum computing.  We concluded that utilization of quantum computing on a daily or weekly scale is not yet feasible - at least not in the type of businesses and customer segments we were studying during our award period.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 05/30/2022
Modified by: Vesselin Gueorguiev
